metadata.title: Motion, Force and Work
metadata.subject: Science
metadata.description: This chapter explains the concepts of motion, distance, displacement, speed, velocity, acceleration, force, and work.

concepts.title: Motion, Distance, Displacement, Speed and Velocity
concepts.content: Motion is the change in the position of an object with time. Distance is the length of the actual path travelled by an object. Displacement is the minimum distance between the starting and finishing points. Speed is the rate of change of distance. Velocity is the rate of change of displacement.

examples.text: A car travelling from one city to another covers a certain distance.
A boy running in a circular path covers a distance, but his displacement is zero after one round.

keyPoints.text: Distance is a scalar quantity, while displacement is a vector quantity.
Speed is a scalar quantity, while velocity is a vector quantity.

concepts.funFact: The Earth is always in motion, travelling at a speed of about 30 km/s around the Sun!

concepts.title: Force
concepts.content: Force is a push or pull that can change the state of motion of an object. Force can change the speed, direction, or shape of an object.

examples.text: Pushing a door to open it.
Kicking a football to change its direction.

keyPoints.text: Force has both magnitude and direction.
The SI unit of force is Newton (N).

concepts.funFact: Gravity is a force that pulls everything towards the center of the Earth.

concepts.title: Work
concepts.content: Work is said to be done when a force applied to an object causes a displacement of the object.

examples.text: Lifting a book from a table.
Pushing a cart and moving it.

keyPoints.text: Work done is zero if there is no displacement.
The SI unit of work is Joule (J).

concepts.funFact: Even if you push a wall for hours, you are doing no work in the scientific sense, because the wall doesn't move!

test.question: A bus travels 100 km in 2 hours. What is its speed?
test.explanation: Speed = Distance / Time = 100 km / 2 h = 50 km/h

test.question: Which of the following is not an effect of force?
test.explanation: Force can change the speed, direction, and shape of an object, but not its mass.

test.question: When is work said to be done?
options: When a force is applied and the object is displaced
When an object is at rest
test.explanation: Work is done only when a force causes a displacement.

test.question: What is the displacement of a person who walks 5 m east and then 5 m west?
test.explanation: The person returns to the starting point, so the displacement is zero.

test.question: What is the force that opposes motion?
test.explanation: Friction is the force that opposes motion between two surfaces in contact.

test.question: If you lift a box of 10 N to a height of 2 m, how much work have you done?
test.explanation: Work = Force x Distance = 10 N x 2 m = 20 J

test.question: Which of these is a scalar quantity?
test.explanation: Distance has only magnitude, so it is a scalar quantity. The others have both magnitude and direction.

test.question: A ball is thrown upwards. What is the work done by gravity?
test.explanation: Gravity acts downwards, while the displacement is upwards. So, the work done by gravity is negative.

commonMisconceptions: Distance and displacement are the same.
Force is always in the direction of motion.
